title: 108_hr1106
content:
The "Fremont-Madison Conveyance Act" defines terms like "District" and "Secretary" and involves the conveyance of facilities. The Secretary of the Interior is required to convey water distribution and drainage system components to the Fremont-Madison Irrigation District in Idaho. If the conveyance is not completed by a certain date, a report must be submitted to Congress explaining the delay. The Secretary will require the District to pay administrative costs for the conveyance and related activities, as well as the net present value of remaining obligations owed to the United States. Amounts received will be deposited into the Reclamation Fund. In conveying the Teton Exchange Wells, the Secretary will also transfer the Idaho Department of Water Resources permit number 22-7022 and all equipment related to the wells. The water service contract between the Secretary and the District is extended until all conditions in the Act are met. Prior to conveyance, environmental reviews must be completed as per the Memorandum of Agreement. SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW

Before conveyance, the Secretary must complete all environmental reviews as outlined in the Memorandum of Agreement. 

SEC. 7. LIABILITY

After conveyance, the United States is not liable for damages except for negligence prior to the conveyance date. Liability remains as provided in chapter 171 of title 28, United States Code.

SEC. 8. WATER SUPPLY TO DISTRICT LANDS. The acreage eligible for water supply from the Minidoka Project and Teton Basin Projects in the District is increased to include all lands as of the enactment date. This increase does not affect existing water storage contracts or State water law. Additionally, drought management planning is addressed. Within 60 days of enactment, the Secretary will collaborate with stakeholders in the Henry's Fork watershed to initiate drought management planning for all water uses. A report with the final drought management plan must be submitted to Congress within 18 months. SEC. 10. EFFECT. This section clarifies that the Act does not affect the rights of any person or the water rights of the Shoshone-Bannock Tribes. Conveyances under the Act will not impact existing contracts or state laws related to water use.
